pullRequest.body:
Defines the normal form of meromorphic functions and provides API for continuous extension, as discussed [on Zulip](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/channel/287929-mathlib4/topic/API.20for.20continuous.20extension.20of.20meromorphic.20functions). More material will be provided in upcoming PRs.

This material is used in [Project VD](https://github.com/kebekus/ProjectVD), which aims to formalize Value Distribution Theory for meromorphic functions on the complex plane.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

### PR summary [08d9c73bfa](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/22867/commits/08d9c73bfacea541aa866f03764ec9b31128882f)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.Analysis.Meromorphic.NormalFormAt` (new file)|1644|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ AnalyticAt.MeromorphicNFAt`
`+ MeromorphicAt.eqOn_compl_singleton_toNF`
`+ MeromorphicAt.eq_nhdNE_toMeromorphicNFAt`
`+ MeromorphicAt.meromorphicNFAt_toNF`
`+ MeromorphicNFAt`
`+ MeromorphicNFAt.meromorphicAt`
`+ MeromorphicNFAt.nonneg_order_iff_analyticAt`
`+ MeromorphicNFAt.toNF_eq_id`
`+ eventuallyEq_nhds_of_eventuallyEq_nhdsNE`
`+ meromorphicNFAt_congr`
`+ meromorphicNFAt_iff_analyticAt_or`
`+ toMeromorphicNFAt`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>
I took a careful look through this and found some golfs, and a few minor renaming suggestions, but the overall design looks great. Thanks for this nice contribution!
I think this name should swap its components, since the NE is on the LHS of the iff.
Upsetting. Fixed.

```suggestion
or if it can locally be written as `fun z  (z - x) ^ n  g` where `g` is
```

```suggestion
    ( (n : ),  g :   E, (AnalyticAt  g x)  (g x  0)  (f =[ x] ( - x) ^ n  g )) :=
  Iff.rfl
```

or
```suggestion
    ( (n : ),  g :   E, (AnalyticAt  g x)  (g x  0)  (f =[ x] ( - x) ^ n  g)) :=
  .rfl
```

```suggestion
there, or if it has a pole at `x` and takes the default value `0`. -/
```

You have a lot of unnecessary brackets. Also your indenting is a bit confusing
```suggestion
  f =[ x] 0 
     (n : ) (g :   E), AnalyticAt  g x  g x  0  f =[ x] ( - x) ^ n  g
```

This is already the equation lemma. You know you can do `rw [MeromorphicNFAt]`, right?
```suggestion
```

```suggestion
    MeromorphicNFAt f x  AnalyticAt  f x  hf.order < 0  f x = 0 := by
```

Isn't this true as
```suggestion
theorem MeromorphicAt.meromorphicNFAt_iff :
    MeromorphicNFAt f x  MeromorphicAt f x  (AnalyticAt  f x  hf.order < 0  f x = 0) := by
```

This is probably true, and might well be useful  but I fear the compiler will reject your formulation because `hf.order` is not defined. There must be a way to fix that, but I cannot formulate something that compiles. Please advise.

Here it is:
```suggestion
theorem MeromorphicAt.meromorphicNFAt_iff :
    MeromorphicNFAt f x  AnalyticAt  f x   hf : MeromorphicAt f x, hf.order < 0  f x = 0 := by
```
but really `MeromorphicAt.order` should take `f` as an argument and return a junk value if `f` isn't meromorphic
Roger. I implemented your suggestion. I tend to not touch `MeromorphicAt.order` unless this has been discussed on Zulip with the people who introduced it

```suggestion
    f =[[] z] g  f =[ z] g := by
```

Don't you need only assume one of the functions is analytic?
```suggestion
theorem eventuallyEq_nhdNE_iff_eventuallyEq_nhd (hf : AnalyticAt  f z) :
  f =[[] z] g  f =[ z] g := by
```

I think you need both. For a counterexample, take `f = 0` and take `g` as the indicator function of a point. Then, `f` is analytic and the two agree in a punctured neighbourhood, but in no regular neighbourhood of that point.

So you can get away with
```suggestion
theorem eventuallyEq_nhdNE_iff_eventuallyEq_nhd (hf : AnalyticAt  f z) (hg : ContinuousAt  g z) :
    f =[[] z] g  f =[ z] g := by
```
right? I'm thinking it might be useful as a way to prove analycity of `g` knowing only analycity of `f`
I see what you are saying. Going further down that line, it will suffice to assume continuity for `f` as well. Let me see if I can work this out before going to the office.
I agree with Yal, this doesn't seem to be specific to analytic functions.
Agreed. Maybe the theorem should just be removed. I am traveling right now, will come back to this ASAP.

As Yal's comments point out, the theorem has nothing to do with `AnalyticAt`, but is a statement about functions that are continuous at non-isolated points of a topological space. I have therefore removed the statement from `IsolatedZeros.lean` and added a short private lemma in `NormalFormAt.lean`, where I use it twice.

I made this a private lemma because I found it easier to state a quick lemma for analytic functions, compared to the effort involved in stating/proving/applying a lemma on continuous functions that requires me to argue that points in topological spaces underlying nontrivially normed fields are non-isolated.

```suggestion
meromorphic functions is therefore huge, and `=[codiscreteWithin U]` defines an
```
`intro` & `rcases` can be combined with `rintro`, and you can also absorb the `obtain` in 2nd branch
Understood & implemented.

```suggestion
      rcases hf with h | n, g, hg, _, hg
```
and then you don't need the `obtain` later
ditto

This is extremely golfable. It can be done in 2 lines in term mode but it becomes rather unreadable. Perhaps a happy medium between brevity and readability is something like this:
```suggestion
/-- Meromorphicity in normal form is a local property. -/
theorem meromorphicNFAt_congr {g :   E} (hfg : f =[ x] g) :
    MeromorphicNFAt f x  MeromorphicNFAt g x := by
  constructor
   rintro (h | n, h, hh, hh, hh)
     exact Or.inl (hfg.symm.trans h)
     exact Or.inr n, h, hh, hh, hfg.symm.trans hh
   rintro (h | n, h, hh, hh, hh)
     exact Or.inl (hfg.trans h)
     exact Or.inr n, h, hh, hh, hfg.trans hh
```
Note the use of `rintro`, which is a shorthand for `intro ` followed by `rcases`; and combining the `rcases` and `obtain` lines in your proof into a single step by nesting the `< >` pattern inside the `( | )` pattern.
Can `aesop` or `unfold MeromorphicNFAt; aesop` prove it?
I doubt it, if you don't give `aesop` the `.trans` and `.symm` lemmas.
Oh, my! There is so much to learn  I will make an effort to remember next time, but you know my age.

```suggestion
order, then it is analytic. -/
```
(for consistency)
Is it worth having the `iff` statement analytic iff meromorphicNF with nonnegative order?
Agreed. Implemented.
I wouldn't put the `of` in the name here.
Implemented.

```suggestion
    apply eventuallyEq_nhds_of_eventuallyEq_nhdsNE (hf.toNF_id_on_nhdNE.symm.trans hg)
    simp only [MeromorphicAt.toNF, ne_eq, Function.update_self, Pi.smul_apply',
      Pi.pow_apply, sub_self,  hn, WithTop.coe_eq_coe]
    split_ifs with hf
     obtain hG, _, hG := Classical.choose_spec ((hf.order_eq_int_iff 0).1 (hf  hn.symm))
      apply Filter.EventuallyEq.eq_of_nhds
      rw [ hG.eventuallyEq_nhdNE_iff_eventuallyEq_nhd (by fun_prop)]
      filter_upwards [hg, hG]
      simp_all
     simp [hf, zero_zpow]
```

You can unfold definitions with `rw` or `simp only`: 
```suggestion
    simp only [MeromorphicAt.toNF, WithTop.coe_zero, ne_eq, Function.update_self]
```

```suggestion
     simpa [(hf.meromorphicAt.order_eq_top_iff).2 (hf.filter_mono nhdsWithin_le_nhds)] 
        using hf.eq_of_nhds
```
When you have a `simp` then an `exact`, you can use `simpa`; and then it's terminal, so you don't need to specify all the simp lemmas explicitly.

```suggestion
## TODO

Establish further properties of meromorphic functions in normal form, such
```

```suggestion
lemma MeromorphicAt.eqOn_compl_singleton_toNF (hf : MeromorphicAt f x) :
    Set.EqOn f hf.toNF {x} :=+
    
```
I assume that the ":=+" is a typo and you wanted the change the name. Implemented that.

```suggestion
theorem MeromorphicAt.meromorphicNFAt_toNF (hf : MeromorphicAt f x) :
```

This will display as `MeromorphicAt.toNF ` in the infoview, meaning you won't know what function you are taking the normal form of. Instead I would do
```suggestion
variable (f) in
/-- Convert a meromorphic function to normal form at `x` by changing its value at `x`. -/
noncomputable def MeromorphicAt.toNF (hf : MeromorphicAt f x) :
      E := by
```
and by this point it's not clear why you're asking for the meromorphicity assumption anymore, so the following seems best
```suggestion
variable (f) in
/-- Convert a meromorphic function to normal form at `x` by changing its value at `x`. -/
noncomputable def toMeromorphicNFAt :   E :=
  if hf : MeromorphicAt f x then currentDef else 0
```

@YaelDillies I am not 100% sure I understand. I get a lot of errors with this. Could it be that `x` must also be included someplace? I tried the following:

```
variable (f) (x) in
/-- Convert a meromorphic function to normal form at `x` by changing its value at `x`. -/
noncomputable def Function.toMeromorphicNFAt :
      E := by
  by_cases hf : MeromorphicAt f x
   classical -- do not complain about decidability issues in Function.update
    apply Function.update f x
    by_cases hf : hf.order = (0 : )
     rw [hf.order_eq_int_iff] at hf
      exact (Classical.choose hf) x
     exact 0
   exact 0
```
This also allows writing `f.toMeromorphicNFAt x`, which is maybe a little nicer as notation. What do you think?
Yes sorry, should be mentioning `x` indeed
Thanks for the extremely fast response. Will implement this now.
Ok, done. Thanks for the suggestion.

```suggestion
theorem meromorphicNFAt_iff_analyticAt_or :
    MeromorphicNFAt f x  AnalyticAt  f x   hf : MeromorphicAt f x, hf.order < 0  f x = 0 := by
```
or something like that

I don't really see the point of the `Function` namespace given that eg `MeromorphicAt` isn't `Function.MeromorphicAt`. What about
```suggestion
noncomputable def meromorphicNormaliseAt :
      E := by
```
or, shorter,
```suggestion
noncomputable def meromorphicNormAt :
      E := by
```

@YaelDillies If I have the option, I would rather stay with `Function.toMeromorphicNFAt`, because it gives the notation `f.toMeromorphicAt x` instead of `mermorphicNormAt f x`. I believe this is preferable for the following reasons:
- succinct, descriptive, and intuitive: the prefix `to` indicates that this is a conversion to `MeromorphicAt`.
- unambiguous: `mermorphicNormAt f x` suggests you are taking the meromorphic norm at `f x`.

You asked for the difference between `Function.toMeromorphicNFAt` and `MeromorphicAt`. IMHO, the difference is that `Function.toMeromorphicNFAt` is a transformation of functions [akin to [Function.invFun](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Logic/Function/Basic.html#Function.invFun)] and `MeromorphicAt` is an adjective [akin to [Differentiable](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/Calculus/FDeriv/Basic.html#Differentiable)].

How do you feel about this?
Im not sure its a good idea to add lemmas about very specific topics to the namespaces of very general objects like Function or Set.
I am not sure I understand why that is a bad idea. Can you help? How do you feel about `toMeromorphicNFAt`?
One issue is eg that it becomes harder to name your lemmas, because half the API is outside the `Function` namespace and the other half inside
@YaelDillies @loefflerd Roger. Is `toMeromorphicNFAt` an alternative?
Yes sure, works for me!
Ok, then let's go for that. Will implement.
PS: Is there a way we can have `f.toMeromorphicNFAt` using abbreviations or some other wizardry?
Implemented.

```suggestion
/-- Two analytic functions agree on a punctured neighborhood iff they agree on a neighborhood. -/
private lemma AnalyticAt.eventuallyEq_nhdNE_iff_eventuallyEq_nhd {g :   E} {z : }
```

```suggestion
lemma MeromorphicAt.eq_nhdNE_toMeromorphicNFAt (hf : MeromorphicAt f x) :
```

```suggestion
protected theorem MeromorphicNFAt.toMeromorphicNFAt :
```
(if `hf` doesn't hold, then `toMeromorphicNFAt f x = 0` is in mero-nf)
I accept your suggestion, but I am not 100% sure what it does. What does the `protected` do?

```suggestion
theorem MeromorphicNFAt.toNF_eq_self (hf : MeromorphicNFAt f x) :
    toMeromorphicNFAt f x = f := by
```
and can you prove the iff version?
Will do.

pullRequest.title: feat: API for continuous extension of meromorphic functions
